head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Internet Consumer Protection Law

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Internet Consumer Protection Law

body.head.byline: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Compiled by John Sullivan

block.p: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will broaden consumer protections for New Yorkers who shop online. The law will bring the protections for online shoppers in line with those for consumers who buy goods over the phone or by mail. Among other provisions, it will prohibit online retailers from accepting an order they cannot ship within 30 days and require advertising and promotional materials to include the retailer's legal name, address and the conditions under which refunds will be issued. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that his office's Internet Bureau received 1,000 consumer complaints last year and that the bill, passed by the Legislature in May, would ''put businesses on notice that the Internet is no longer the Wild West of commerce.''
